data.title: Optimal box
data.solution:
l, w, h = gets.split.map(&:to_i)
item_dims = [l, w, h].sort
boxes = []

n = gets.to_i
n.times do |i|
    bl, bw, bh = gets.split.map(&:to_i)
    box_dims = [bl, bw, bh].sort
    fits = box_dims.zip(item_dims).all? { |box_dim, item_dim| box_dim > item_dim }
    boxes << {volume: bl * bw * bh, index: i} if fits
end

optimal_box = boxes.min_by { |box| [box[:volume], box[:index]] }
puts boxes.empty? ? "NONE" : optimal_box[:index]
data.statement:
Given the dimensions of a certain item (length, width and height) and the dimensions of [[N]] boxes, your task is to output the <<index of the optimal box>> for that item, that is, the box with the <<smallest volume in which the item fits in>> (the volume of a box is equals to the product of its length, width and height).

The item only fits in a box if its dimensions are less than the dimensions of the box (e.g. if the item has dimensions {{10}}x{{15}}x{{20}}, it needs a box that has at least {{11}}x{{16}}x{{21}}). The item <<can be rotated any way>> in order to fit in the box, as long as it doesn't lie diagonally.

If more than one is the smallest, output the first one in order of appearance. If there's no box big enough to hold the item, then output {{NONE}}.
data.stubGenerator:
read l:int w:int h:int
read n:int
loop n read bl:int bw:int bh:int
write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1>> Three integers [[L]], [[W]] and [[H]] for the length, width and height of the item.
<<Line  2>> An integer [[N]] for the number of boxes.
<<Next [[N]] lines>> Three integers [[BL]], [[BW]] and [[BH]] for the length, width and height of each box.
data.outputDescription: A single line with the 0-based index of the optimal box or the word {{NONE}} if there's no box big enough to hold the item.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Given the dimensions of a certain item (length, width and height) and the dimensions of N boxes, your task is to output the index of the optimal box for that item, that is, the box with the smallest volume in which the item fits in (the volume of a box is equals to the product of its length, width and height).

The item only fits in a box if its dimensions are less than the dimensions of the box (e.g. if the item has dimensions 10x15x20, it needs a box that has at least 11x16x21). The item can be rotated any way in order to fit in the box, as long as it doesn't lie diagonally.

If more than one is the smallest, output the first one in order of appearance. If there's no box big enough to hold the item, then output NONE.
Input
Line 1 Three integers L, W and H for the length, width and height of the item.
Line 2 An integer N for the number of boxes.
Next N lines Three integers BL, BW and BH for the length, width and height of each box.
Output
A single line with the 0-based index of the optimal box or the word NONE if there's no box big enough to hold the item.
Constraints
1 ≤ L, W, H, BL, BW, BH ≤ 1000
2 ≤ N ≤ 10
Example
Input
19 20 5
5
18 18 18
22 30 12
20 20 6
18 20 21
15 21 24
Output
3
